ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In this course, I developed a strong foundation for studying the Roman republic. I engaged with foundational works in the field while encountering more recent research that has critiqued, affirmed, and/or challenged seminal texts. We also gained a great deal of exposure to t he varieties of ancient sources available for the period.
Knowledge about the inner workings of the late Roman Republic.
I gained a much better understanding of the history of the Late Roman Republic, the causes of the Republic's downfall, and the scholarship pertaining to that period.
I developed more extensive knowledge of and greater appreciation for the many methodologies applied to the historical evidence for the period of the late Roman republic.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: OVerall the course was excellent. Easily my favorite course this term. that said, I would have liked to grapple with more complete secondary texts (e.g. Syme, Gruehn, etc.) rather than only select portions.

The course's strengths were a strong reading list, active student engagement, and excellent teaching. It might be worth considering whether spreading out student presentations on paper topics over several classes, so as to allow slightly fuller discussion.
This course was excellent at creating discussion. The idea of submitting questions in advance really helped with this and I think it was a major strength.

The strengths of this course were its demanding list of weekly readings and its ideal size. Everyone had a chance to speak their piece at length every week, and every participant contributed their own unique perspective to the discussion. Discussions in this class could easily have run on into a third hour, if such a thing could be arranged. Three-hour seminars are mentally (and physically!) trying, but I think the extra time would be well-spent.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES!!! WIthout reservations. Andrew Johnston is a remarkable professor.
I would recommend this course highly to a student with a strong background in Roman history who wanted to examine its nuances in greater detail.
